network_memory.content:
🎯 ORIGINAL TASK REQUIREMENT:
A paper about AI regulation that was originally submitted to arXiv.org in June 2022 shows a figure with three axes, where each axis has a label word at both ends. Which of these words is used to describe a type of society in a Physics and Society article submitted to arXiv.org on August 11, 2016?
================================================================================
Step 1 - Current Task Input:
A paper about AI regulation that was originally submitted to arXiv.org in June 2022 shows a figure with three axes, where each axis has a label word at both ends. Which of these words is used to describe a type of society in a Physics and Society article submitted to arXiv.org on August 11, 2016?

⚠️  REMEMBER: All your work must contribute to answering the ORIGINAL TASK above!

Tool result: Observed output of cmd `browser_use` executed:
Search results for 'Physics and Society article arXiv August 11, 2016':

1. Detecting highly cyclic structure with complex eigenpairs
   URL: http://arxiv.org/abs/1609.05740v1
   Description: Published: 2016-08-24 | Many large, real-world complex networks have rich community structure that a network scientist seeks to understand. These communities may overlap or have intricate internal structure. Extracting commu...
   Content: [1609.05740v1] Detecting highly cyclic structure with complex eigenpairs Computer Science > Social and Information Networks arXiv:1609.05740v1 (cs) [Submitted on 24 Aug 2016] Title: Detecting highly cyclic structure with complex eigenpairs Authors: Christine Klymko , Geoffrey Sanders View a PDF of the paper titled Detecting highly cyclic structure with complex eigenpairs, by Christine Klymko and Geoffrey Sanders View PDF Abstract: Many large, real-world complex networks have rich community structure that a network scientist seeks to understand. These communities may overlap or have intricate internal structure. Extracting communities with particular topological structure, even when they overlap with other communities, is a powerful capability that would provide novel avenues of focusing in on structure of interest. In this work we consider extracting highly-cyclic regions of directed graphs (digraphs). We demonstrate that embeddings derived from complex-valued eigenvectors associated w...

Search results for 'arXiv AI regulation June 2022 figure axes':

1. Best of Both Worlds Model Selection
   URL: http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.14912v1
   Description: Published: 2022-06-29 | We study the problem of model selection in bandit scenarios in the presence of nested policy classes, with the goal of obtaining simultaneous adversarial and stochastic ("best of both worlds") high-pr...
   Content: [2206.14912v1] Best of Both Worlds Model Selection Computer Science > Machine Learning arXiv:2206.14912v1 (cs) [Submitted on 29 Jun 2022] Title: Best of Both Worlds Model Selection Authors: Aldo Pacchiano , Christoph Dann , Claudio Gentile View a PDF of the paper titled Best of Both Worlds Model Selection, by Aldo Pacchiano and 2 other authors View PDF Abstract: We study the problem of model selection in bandit scenarios in the presence of nested policy classes, with the goal of obtaining simultaneous adversarial and stochastic ("best of both worlds") high-probability regret guarantees. Our approach requires that each base learner comes with a candidate regret bound that may or may not hold, while our meta algorithm plays each base learner according to a schedule that keeps the base learner's candidate regret bounds balanced until they are detected to violate their guarantees. We develop careful mis-specification tests specifically designed to blend the above model selection criterion...

   Content: [1609.05740v1] Detecting highly cyclic structure with complex eigenpairs Computer Science > Social and Information Networks arXiv:1609.05740v1 (cs) [Submitted on 24 Aug 2016] Title: Detecting highly cyclic structure with complex eigenpairs Authors: Christine Klymko , Geoffrey Sanders View a PDF of the paper titled Detecting highly cyclic structure with complex eigenpairs, by Christine Klymko and Geoffrey Sanders View PDF Abstract: Many large, real-world complex networks have rich community structure that a network scientist seeks to understand. These communities may overlap or have intricate internal structure. Extracting communities with particular topological structure, even when they overlap with other communities, is a powerful capability that would provide novel avenues of focusing in on structure of interest.
